P.title: Will Europa be the first place humanity will discover extraterrestrial life, if it is discovered before 2045?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extra terrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this question will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this question will be Annulled.
Note: extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.

This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data
", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_and_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('c34ffbfe-6ccb-4408-a8a7-8587028f4ca3'), title='Will both of the following occur: (1) A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024, and (2) there will be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?', body='Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if (1) one of the following individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024: Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, or Barron Trump; and (2) by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. The data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible, and the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_or_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('87f8dcfb-2168-4824-bead-49376851fb89'), title='Will either of the following occur: (a) A member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 (b) There be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?', body='Resolution Criteria

GENREAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want mentioning the reasoning of your predictions as well as how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  For each prediction you are welcome to be as verbose as you want. If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P etc).  Here, ONLY output the labels and its associated predictions and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
    P: 0.xx
    not_P: 0.xx
    P_or_Q: 0.xx
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print out the mathematical rule and the associated numbers associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!}

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occured before.
        Note that changing the probability of one given variable for one consistency check will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that all changes  
        your correction needs to ENSURE that it still passes other consistency checks too.
        If there were no violations found then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
        P: 0.xx
        not_P: 0.xx
        P_or_Q: 0.xx
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!
elicitation_metadata.chain_of_thought:
RECEIVED

P: #Reasons P may or may not happen
not_P: #Reasons not_P may or may not happen
para_P: #Reasons para_P may or may not happen
Q: #Reasons Q may or may not happen
P_and_Q: #Reasons P_and_Q may or may not happen
P_or_Q: #Reasons P_or_Q may or may not happen
Q_and_not_P: #Reasons Q_and_not_P may or may not happen
Q_given_P: #Reasons Q_given_P may or may not happen

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.27 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.83 + 0.23 - 0.33 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73, + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.83 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.83 - 0.10 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.73 = 0.73 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10

0.73

RECEIVED

P: #Reasons P may or may not happen
not_P: #Reasons not_P may or may not happen
para_P: #Reasons para_P may or may not happen
Q: #Reasons Q may or may not happen
P_and_Q: #Reasons P_and_Q may or may not happen
P_or_Q: #Reasons P_or_Q may or may not happen
Q_and_not_P: #Reasons Q_and_not_P may or may not happen
Q_given_P: #Reasons Q_given_P may or may not happen

not_P: 0.35
para_P: 0.76
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.71
Q_and_not_P: 0.12
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.35 is FALSE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.71 + 0.23 - 0.33 is FALSE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73 + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.71 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is FALSE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.71 - 0.12 is FALSE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.73 = 0.76 is FALSE

neg, andor, or, but, para consistency checks failed!

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

0.73

RECEIVED

For the questions provided, I will analyze each event (P, not_P, Q, etc.) and provide reasoning for the probability estimates based on the context of the questions and their interdependencies.

1. **P (Will a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?)**: Given the current political landscape and the prominence of the Trump family in Republican politics, I estimate a fairly high probability for this event. The Trump family has significant support within the party, and Donald Trump himself remains a strong candidate. Therefore, I estimate P at around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will no member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?)**: This event is the direct negation of P. If P is estimated at 0.65, then not_P would be 1 - 0.65 = 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is it possible that a member of the Trump family will secure the Republican nomination for the US Presidency in 2024?)**: Since this is essentially asking the same question as P, the probabilities should align. Therefore, I estimate para_P at 0.65 as well.

4. **Q (Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?)**: Based on current climate models and trends, there is a significant chance that global temperatures will reach or exceed this threshold due to ongoing climate change. Therefore, I estimate Q at 0.75.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: For this event, we need to consider the joint probability of both events occurring. Assuming P and Q are somewhat independent, we can estimate P_and_Q as P * Q = 0.65 * 0.75 = 0.4875, which I will round to 0.49.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This is calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Substituting the values gives us 0.65 + 0.75 - 0.49 = 0.91.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q occur and no member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee?)**: This involves the intersection of Q and not_P. Assuming some independence, I estimate this as Q * not_P = 0.75 * 0.35 = 0.2625, which I will round to 0.26.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that a member of the Trump family is the nominee, will there be at least 2˚C of global warming?)**: This is a conditional probability that assumes P is true. Given that climate change is a broader issue and not directly influenced by political events, I will estimate Q_given_P at 0.75, as it remains unchanged by the condition.

In terms of consistency, I will ensure that these estimates adhere to the rules provided. The relationships between P, not_P, and the other events will be critical in ensuring that all estimates are coherent and do not violate any of the consistency rules.

P: 0.65
not_P: 0.35
para_P: 0.65
Q: 0.75
P_and_Q: 0.49
P_or_Q: 0.91
Q_and_not_P: 0.26
Q_given_P: 0.75

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.65 = 1 - 0.35 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.91 + 0.49 - 0.75 is FALSE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.75 - 1, 0) <= 0.49 <= min(0.65, 0.75) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.75) <= 0.91 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.75) is FALSE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.91 - 0.26 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.49 / 0.75 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE

andor, or consistency checks failed!

not_P: 0.35
para_P: 0.65
Q: 0.75
P_and_Q: 0.49
P_or_Q: 0.91
Q_and_not_P: 0.26
Q_given_P: 0.75

0.65

Q_and_not_P.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) We find life on Mars by 2050 and (b) Europa is not the first place humanity discovers extraterrestrial life, if it is discovered before 2045?
Q_and_not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following occur:
(a) Prominent, highly respected scientific organizations announce that humans have discovered unambiguous evidence of current or past life on Mars, independent of life that was carried from Earth to Mars via human-designed missions, before January 1, 2050.
(b) Humanity discovers convincing evidence of life anywhere other than Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extraterrestrial life on Europa. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly on Europa prior to anywhere else, this question will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this question will be Annulled.
Note: extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.
If either of these conditions is not met, this question will resolve as No.

For the questions provided, we need to assess the probability of each event occurring, particularly focusing on the potential candidacy of a member of the Trump family for the Republican nomination in 2024, as well as the likelihood of global warming reaching at least 2 degrees Celsius by 2100.

**P (Trump Family Nominee)**: This question likely has a higher probability given the prominence of the Trump family in recent Republican politics. Factors influencing this include Donald Trump's previous presidency and continued popularity within the party. Given these factors, I might estimate P to be around 0.65.

**not_P (No Trump Family Nominee)**: This is the complement of P. If P is around 0.65, then not_P would be approximately 0.35. 

**para_P (Possibility of Trump Family Nominee)**: This is essentially the same as P since it asks if it's possible for a family member to secure the nomination. Thus, para_P would also be around 0.65. 

**Q (Global Warming)**: The likelihood of reaching at least 2 degrees Celsius of warming by 2100 is a contentious issue, but scientific consensus leans towards significant global warming occurring if current trends continue. I would estimate Q to be around 0.70 based on prevailing climate models and predictions.

**P_and_Q (Both Events Occur)**: This question assesses the joint probability of both P and Q occurring. Given the independence of these events, I could estimate this to be the product of their individual probabilities. Therefore, P_and_Q could be around 0.65 * 0.70 = 0.455.

**P_or_Q (Either Event Occurs)**: This can be calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Therefore, P_or_Q would be around 0.65 + 0.70 - 0.455 = 0.895.

**Q_and_not_P (Global Warming and No Trump Nominee)**: This question combines two events, and if we assume independence, we can estimate this as Q * not_P, which would be around 0.70 * 0.35 = 0.245.

**Q_given_P (Global Warming Given Trump Nominee)**: This conditional probability can be complex, but if we assume that the nomination of a Trump family member does not significantly impact the likelihood of global warming, we might estimate this as being similar to Q, hence around 0.70.

Overall, I will ensure that these estimates adhere to the consistency rules provided, making necessary adjustments to ensure that all relationships hold true. The independence of P and Q is crucial in calculating the joint probabilities, and I will evaluate each rule carefully to ensure compliance.

P_or_Q.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Europa be the first place humanity will discover extraterrestrial life, if it is discovered before 2045? (b) We find life on Mars by 2050?
P_or_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if either of the following occurs:
(a) Humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extraterrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this part will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this part will be Annulled. Note: extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.
(b) Prominent, highly respected scientific organizations announce that humans have discovered unambiguous evidence of current or past life on Mars, independent of life that was carried from Earth to Mars via human-designed missions, before January 1, 2050. If this has not happened before January 1, 2050, this part will resolve as No.

This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data

For the questions provided, I will evaluate the probability estimates based on the relationships between the events and the logical consistency rules outlined.

1. **P (Trump family member as nominee)**: This event is likely given the prominence of the Trump family in the Republican Party and Donald Trump's previous candidacy. I would estimate this at around 0.60.

2. **not_P (No Trump family member as nominee)**: This is the complement of P and should be estimated as 1 - P, which would be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Possibility of Trump family member securing nomination)**: This is essentially the same as P, so I would assign the same probability of 0.60.

4. **Q (At least 2˚C global warming by 2100)**: Given current climate trends, there is a strong possibility of significant warming, so I would estimate this at 0.75.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This probability is generally lower than either P or Q alone, as both need to happen. I would estimate it at about 0.45, assuming a moderate correlation between the two events.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This is likely higher than both individual probabilities, so I can estimate it at 0.85, considering the independence of the two events.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while not P)**: This is contingent on Q happening while P does not. Given the estimates, I would assign this a probability of about 0.30.

8. **Q_given_P (Q given P occurs)**: This is a conditional probability, and I would estimate it at 0.70, reflecting the likelihood of significant warming if a Trump family member is nominated.

Now, I will check these estimates against the consistency rules to ensure they align correctly.
